author: Shiv Sunny
text:
Responding to the recent solidarity march by JNU students, thousands of people — led by ex-servicemen — walked down from Rajghat to Jantar Mantar on Sunday to protest the alleged “anti-national” activities taking place on the university campus.

Organised under the banner ‘Save the nation’, the protest comprised Delhiites who raised pro-India and anti-Pakistan slogans, while lashing out at the JNU students.

According to organisers, the number of protesters was around 1 lakh, but the police pegged the number around 30,000.

Led by dozens of ex-Army personnel and attended by ABVP students, BJP activists and RSS members, the march began from Rajghat at 10.30 am. It crossed the busy ITO intersection before arriving at Jantar Mantar, where the leaders addressed the gathering. The march resulted in massive traffic jams on the way, at ITO in particular, for at least two hours. However diversion of traffic minimised the impact.

A lot of the slogans raised called for death to the JNU students who allegedly shouted pro-Pakistan slogans. Devesh Sharma, a retired serviceman, said he decided to attend the march to express “anguish” against “anti-national activities” taking place at JNU. Most protesters, however, said they were not associated with any political party.

“The incident at JNU was the not the handiwork of a few students. Foreign funding helped organise the event,” said another retired Army officer.
title: Another solidarity march, this time against JNU
